The Daily

Jane Austen’s Uncommon Compassion

By Alexandra Schwartz
December 16, 2025
You’re reading The New Yorker’s daily newsletter, a guide to our top stories, featuring exclusive insights from our writers and editors. Sign up to receive it in your inbox.

After a weekend of violence, the President is only making things worse, David Remnick writes. Plus, we’re reflecting on the timelessness of Jane Austen on her two-hundred-and-fiftieth birthday today.

  • The gathering spot for right-wing Zoomers
  • Five things that changed media this year
  • Japan’s fake food is hard not to eat

Alexandra Schwartz
A staff writer, and a co-host of the Critics at Large podcast.

If literature lovers had a calendar all our own, December 16th would be known as Jane’s Day, in honor of the birth of Jane Austen. That momentous event took place two hundred and fifty years ago at Steventon, the village in Hampshire where her father served as rector.

Austen’s life was short—she died in 1817, at the age of forty-one, with her last work, “Sanditon,” still unfinished. Her life as a published writer was shorter still. Though she completed a draft of her first novel, “Sense and Sensibility,” in 1795, she did not manage to bring it out until 1811. The authorship of that book was credited merely to “a Lady;” none of the four novels that she published in her lifetime bore her name. Two and a half centuries later, it still grates to think that this genius, modest as she may have been, felt obliged to go so meekly masked.

Austen’s afterlife is another story. Just before her death, as she prepared her novel “Northanger Abbey” for publication, she added a preface to entreat the public “to bear in mind that thirteen years have passed since it was finished, many more since it was begun, and that during that period, places, manners, books, and opinions have undergone considerable changes.” The period, places, manners, and opinions that Austen wrote about with such bracing perceptiveness have long since vanished, but Austenmania is going as strong as ever. She would undoubtedly be shocked to discover that twenty-first-century fans have spent her semiquincentennial dressing in Regency-era costume and making pilgrimages to her onetime home of Bath, a city that she in fact disliked.

But forget the balls and the barouche-landaus. What is more remarkable, and more meaningful, is that Austen’s books continue to give contemporary readers as much pleasure and solace as they must have done for their original audience. On the one hand, as her Mr. Collins or Mrs. Elton could attest, she is a writer of uniquely withering wit; on the other, of uncommon compassion. No one has written more enduring characters, ones whose company we continue to seek out year after year. “Pride and Prejudice” is the most satisfying love story ever told, and Elizabeth Bennet the most appealing heroine in English literature; her quick intellect and high-spirited independence mark her as a quintessentially modern woman. It is also a complex, ironical tale of something more old-fashioned yet equally essential: a moral education.

Among Austen’s great themes is the value—the necessity—of being wrong in order to learn what is truly right. To be too sure of oneself, to never doubt one’s own reasoning or feelings, is a flaw that her foolish characters brandish, much to our delight. Her wise ones must earn their wisdom through embarrassment or painful disappointment—in other words, by living. So must we. Reading, as Austen well knew, is not separate from experience; it informs and enriches life itself. So, today, on her birthday, crack open an Austen novel for the first or fiftieth time. I’ll be right there with you.

For more: Listen to the hosts of the Critics at Large podcast on our collective romance with Austen, or read Louis Menand on how to misunderstand the Regency-era novelist.
